ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of dizziness triggered specifically by position changes (turning in bed, looking up) with normal hearing.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: High-frequency Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiogram reveals a mild high-frequency loss/notch, likely incidental to the chief complaint of dizziness.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and rule out asymmetric loss associated with retrocochlear pathology.
To evaluate speech understanding and confirm agreement with pure-tone thresholds.
To assess middle ear function given reports of pain and itchiness.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient demonstrates essentially normal hearing sensitivity in the main speech frequencies bilaterally, with a mild high-frequency sensorineural slope and a slight notch at 3000 Hz in the right ear. Speech recognition is excellent. Middle ear function is normal as evidenced by Type A tympanograms and normal acoustic reflexes. The findings do not indicate retrocochlear pathology. The history is strongly suggestive of BPPV.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal 250-4000 Hz, 3000 Hz notch (25 dB HL), sloping to mild loss at 6000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal 250-4000 Hz, sloping to mild loss at 6000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 10 dB HL bilaterally. WRS 96% (Right) and 100% (Left) at 50 dB HL.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds at 500-4000 Hz ipsilateral and contralateral; negative decay.

proposed_items: Referral to ENT specialist for evaluation of dizziness (Dix-Hallpike maneuver)
counseling_actions: Explain that hearing is essentially normal in the speech range.
Inform the patient that the dizziness symptoms are characteristic of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).
Explain that BPPV is caused by crystals in the inner ear moving into the wrong canal and is not related to hearing loss.
Advise that the ENT specialist can perform a maneuver (Epley) to likely resolve the dizziness.
Mention that the ENT can also examine the ear canal for the reported itchiness.

escalation.rationale_short: For confirmation of BPPV via Dix-Hallpike and treatment via Epley maneuver.

expected_outcome: Dix-Hallpike maneuver: Confirmed diagnosis of BPPV.
Epley procedure: Performed and resolved the patient's dizziness.
